name: Agile Ticket Management System
description: Manages agile workflow tickets, assignments, deadlines, and completion status efficiently.

current_prd.elevator_pitch: Our Agile Ticket Management System empowers software development teams to streamline their workflow. It solves the challenge of scattered task information and missed deadlines by providing a centralized dashboard for clear visibility into ticket status, assignments, and progress. Unlike generic task managers, our system is tailored for agile methodologies, ensuring efficient collaboration and timely project delivery.
current_prd.problem_statement: Software development teams often struggle with inefficient agile workflow management due to scattered ticket information, lack of clear assignment visibility, difficulty tracking deadlines, and an inability to quickly assess project progress. This leads to missed deadlines, reduced productivity, and communication breakdowns.
current_prd.solution: The Agile Ticket Management System provides a centralized platform with a comprehensive dashboard to manage agile workflow tickets. It offers features for creating, assigning, tracking, and updating tickets, along with real-time visibility into deadlines, completion status, and team member assignments, thereby improving efficiency and collaboration.

key_features.feature_description: A centralized dashboard displaying an overview of all tickets, their status, assigned team members, deadlines, and completion rates.
Ability to create new tickets with fields for title, description, priority, assignee, due date, and status.
Functionality to assign tickets to specific team members and reassign them as needed.
Tools for setting and tracking deadlines for individual tickets and overall project milestones.
Real-time updates on ticket status (e.g., To Do, In Progress, Done, Blocked) and progress.
User authentication and authorization for secure access and role-based permissions.
APIs for integration with other development tools (e.g., version control, communication platforms).
Scalable architecture to handle increasing numbers of users and tickets without performance degradation.
Admin panel for managing users, roles, projects, and system configurations.
Comprehensive logging and monitoring of system usage, errors, and performance metrics.
Tools and processes for deployment, maintenance, and technical support of the system.

steps: User logs into the system.
System authenticates the user.
System loads the user's personalized dashboard.
User views an overview of tickets, assignments, deadlines, and completion status.
User navigates to the 'Create Ticket' section.
User fills in ticket details (title, description, priority, assignee, due date, status).
User submits the ticket.
System validates the input.
System creates the new ticket and updates the database.
System displays the new ticket on the dashboard.
User selects a ticket from the dashboard.
User clicks on the 'Assign' or 'Reassign' option.
User selects a team member from the dropdown list.
User confirms the assignment.
System updates the ticket with the new assignee.
System notifies the new assignee.
User selects a ticket from the dashboard.
User clicks on the 'Update Status' option.
User selects a new status (e.g., In Progress, Done, Blocked) from the dropdown list.
User saves the changes.
System updates the ticket status in the database.
System reflects the updated status on the dashboard.
Admin logs into the system.
Admin navigates to the 'User Management' section.
Admin views a list of all users.
Admin can add new users, edit existing user roles/permissions, or deactivate users.
System updates user records in the database.
System applies new permissions/roles immediately.

current_prd.success_metrics: Increase in team productivity by 20% within 6 months, 90% on-time project completion rate, 85% user satisfaction score, reduction in missed deadlines by 30%, and 95% system uptime.
current_prd.competitors: Jira, Asana, Trello, Monday.com, ClickUp, Azure DevOps, GitLab Issues, GitHub Issues.
current_prd.vision: To become the leading agile workflow management solution for software development teams, continuously evolving with advanced features like AI-driven insights, enhanced collaboration tools, and seamless integration capabilities, ultimately fostering a highly productive and efficient development ecosystem.

target_audience.name: Software Development Teams
target_audience.pain_points: Scattered task information, difficulty in tracking individual and team progress, missed deadlines, communication overhead, and lack of a centralized platform for agile workflows.
target_audience.demographics: Teams of 5-50 developers, project managers, QA engineers, and product owners. Primarily small to medium-sized businesses (SMBs) and startups.
target_audience.needs_and_goals: Efficiently manage agile sprints, track task progress, improve team collaboration, meet project deadlines, and gain clear visibility into project status.

phasing.rationale: This phase delivers the fundamental capabilities for an agile team to manage tickets. It's a fully functional, albeit basic, system that can be effectively demonstrated to stakeholders to showcase the core value proposition and gather initial feedback.

This phase enhances the core system with essential project management features like deadline tracking and provides the necessary administrative tools for managing users, roles, and system configurations. With these additions, the product is ready for a controlled beta launch to early adopters, allowing for real-world usage and feedback collection.

This phase focuses on expanding the system's utility through integrations, ensuring its robustness and reliability through scalability and performance optimizations, and providing comprehensive tools for operational management and insights. This makes the product suitable for wider enterprise adoption and ensures long-term stability and maintainability.

current_prd.design_principles:
Clarity & Simplicity: The interface should be intuitive and easy to navigate, providing clear information at a glance.
Efficiency: Users should be able to complete tasks quickly and with minimal effort.
Visibility: Provide real-time insights into project progress, individual workloads, and potential bottlenecks.
Consistency: Maintain a unified design language and interaction patterns across the entire application.
Collaboration: Design elements that facilitate team communication and shared understanding of tasks.

user_personas.name: Sarah, The Project Manager
user_personas.goals: Oversee project progress, track team workload, identify bottlenecks, ensure deadlines are met, generate reports.
user_personas.pain_points: Lack of clear overview, difficulty in tracking individual contributions, manual report generation, communication overhead.

user_personas.name: David, The Developer
user_personas.goals: View assigned tickets, update ticket status, track personal deadlines, collaborate with team members, focus on coding.
user_personas.pain_points: Scattered task information, frequent interruptions, unclear priorities, difficulty finding relevant ticket details.

user_personas.name: Emily, The QA Engineer
user_personas.goals: Track tickets for testing, report bugs, verify fixes, ensure software quality.
user_personas.pain_points: Difficulty in reproducing bugs, unclear bug descriptions, slow feedback loops, managing multiple test cases.

steps.description: Logs into the Agile Ticket Management System.
Displays the personalized dashboard.
Reviews overall project progress, identifies overdue tickets, and checks team workload.
Filters tickets by status or assignee to drill down into specific areas.

user_journeys.context: Sarah (Project Manager) needs to get a daily overview of project status.

steps.description: Logs into the system.
Navigates to "My Tickets" or finds the ticket on the dashboard.
Selects the ticket to view details.
Changes the ticket status (e.g., from "In Progress" to "Done").
Adds a comment or attaches relevant files (e.g., code snippets, screenshots).
Saves the changes.
Updates the ticket in the database and reflects the change on the dashboard.

user_journeys.context: David (Developer) needs to update the status of a ticket he is working on.
user_journeys.trigger: Completes a task or makes progress on a ticket.

steps.description: Logs into the system.
Navigates to the "Create New Ticket" section.
Selects "Bug" as the ticket type.
Fills in bug details: title, detailed description, steps to reproduce, expected vs. actual results, severity, priority.
Attaches screenshots or video recordings of the bug.
Assigns the bug to the relevant developer or team.
Sets a due date if applicable.
Submits the new bug ticket.
Creates the new ticket and notifies the assignee.

user_journeys.context: Emily (QA Engineer) needs to report a new bug.

current_prd.sitemap:
Home/Dashboard
Tickets
  - All Tickets
  - My Tickets
  - Create New Ticket
  - Search/Filter Tickets
Projects
  - Project List
  - Project Details (Tickets, Team, Milestones)
Team/Users
  - User List
  - User Profiles
  - User Management (Admin)
Reports/Analytics
  - Project Reports
  - Team Performance
  - Ticket Trends
Settings
  - Profile Settings
  - Account Settings
  - Admin Settings (Roles, Permissions, Integrations)
current_prd.navigation_design:
Primary Navigation: A persistent left-hand sidebar for global navigation, providing quick access to main sections: Dashboard, Tickets, Projects, Team/Users, Reports/Analytics, and Settings. Icons will be used alongside text labels for clarity.
Secondary Navigation: Within major sections like "Tickets" and "Projects", a tabbed or sub-menu navigation will be used to switch between different views (e.g., "All Tickets", "My Tickets", "Create New Ticket").
Contextual Navigation: Breadcrumbs will be used for deeper pages to show the user's current location within the application hierarchy.
Dashboard Widgets: The Dashboard will feature interactive widgets that allow users to quickly access key information and perform common actions (e.g., "Quick Add Ticket", "View Overdue Tickets").

Develop and integrate user authentication module.

current_prd.mermaid_erd_diagram:
erDiagram
  USER ||--o{ PROJECT : manages
  USER ||--o{ TICKET : assigns
  USER ||--o{ TICKET : reports
  USER ||--o{ COMMENT : makes
  USER ||--o{ ATTACHMENT : uploads
  PROJECT ||--o{ TICKET : contains
  TICKET ||--o{ COMMENT : has
  TICKET ||--o{ ATTACHMENT : has

  USER {
    INT id
    VARCHAR username
    VARCHAR email
    VARCHAR password_hash
    VARCHAR role
  }
  PROJECT {
    INT id
    VARCHAR name
    TEXT description
    TIMESTAMP start_date
    TIMESTAMP end_date
  }
  TICKET {
    INT id
    INT project_id
    VARCHAR title
    TEXT description
    VARCHAR type
    VARCHAR status
    VARCHAR priority
    INT assignee_id
    INT reporter_id
    TIMESTAMP due_date
    TIMESTAMP created_at
    TIMESTAMP updated_at
  }
  COMMENT {
    INT id
    INT ticket_id
    INT user_id
    TEXT content
    TIMESTAMP created_at
  }
  ATTACHMENT {
    INT id
    INT ticket_id
    INT user_id
    VARCHAR file_name
    VARCHAR file_path
    VARCHAR file_type
    TIMESTAMP uploaded_at
  }

user_stories.title: Dashboard Overview for Project Manager

user_story.i_want: to see an interactive dashboard with an overview of all tickets, their status, assigned team members, deadlines, and completion rates
user_story.so_that: I can quickly assess project health, identify bottlenecks, and make informed decisions to keep the project on track.

acceptance_criteria: The dashboard displays a summary of total tickets, open tickets, and completed tickets.
The dashboard shows tickets assigned to each team member.
The dashboard highlights tickets nearing or past their deadlines.
The dashboard provides a visual representation of completion rates.
The dashboard allows filtering and sorting of tickets by various criteria (e.g., assignee, status, priority).

user_stories.title: Create and Manage Tickets

user_story.i_want: to create new tickets and manage their details
user_story.so_that: I can accurately document tasks, bugs, and features, and ensure all necessary information is captured for efficient workflow.

acceptance_criteria: User can create a new ticket with a title, description, priority, assignee, and due date.
User can select from a predefined list of statuses (e.g., To Do, In Progress, Done, Blocked).
The system validates required fields before ticket creation.
The newly created ticket is visible on the dashboard and assigned user's ticket list.
User can attach files or links to the ticket description.

user_stories.title: Assign and Reassign Tickets

user_story.i_want: to assign and reassign tickets to specific team members
user_story.so_that: I can distribute workload effectively and ensure tasks are owned by the right individuals.

acceptance_criteria: User can assign a ticket to an available team member from a dropdown list.
User can reassign a ticket to a different team member at any time.
The system sends a notification to the new assignee upon assignment.
The dashboard reflects the updated assignee for the ticket.
Only users with appropriate permissions can assign/reassign tickets.

user_stories.title: Track Ticket Deadlines

user_story.i_want: to track deadlines for my assigned tickets
user_story.so_that: I can prioritize my work, manage my time effectively, and ensure I meet project commitments.

acceptance_criteria: User can set a due date for each ticket during creation or editing.
The system visually highlights tickets that are overdue or approaching their deadline on the dashboard.
Users can filter tickets by deadline status (e.g., 'Due Today', 'Overdue').
The system sends automated reminders for upcoming deadlines to assignees.
Project Managers can view a consolidated report of all deadlines across projects.

user_stories.title: Update Ticket Status and Progress

user_story.i_want: to update the status of my tickets and track my progress
user_story.so_that: my team and project manager have real-time visibility into my work, and I can accurately reflect the current state of my tasks.

acceptance_criteria: User can update the status of a ticket (e.g., To Do, In Progress, Done, Blocked) from the ticket view or dashboard.
The system automatically updates the progress visualization on the dashboard when a ticket status changes.
Users can add comments or notes when updating a ticket status.
The system maintains a history of all status changes for each ticket.
Only the assignee or a user with appropriate permissions can update a ticket's status.

user_stories.title: User Authentication and Role-Based Access

user_story.i_want: to manage user accounts, roles, and permissions securely
user_story.so_that: I can control who has access to the system and what actions they can perform, ensuring data integrity and security.

acceptance_criteria: Admin can create new user accounts with specified roles (e.g., Developer, QA, Project Manager, Admin).
Admin can modify existing user roles and permissions.
Admin can deactivate or delete user accounts.
The system enforces strong password policies for user accounts.
User authentication requires a valid username and password.
The system provides role-based access control to different features and data.

user_stories.title: Integrate with Third-Party Development Tools

user_story.i_want: to integrate the ticket management system with other development tools I use daily
user_story.so_that: I can streamline my workflow, reduce manual data entry, and ensure consistency across all my development activities.

acceptance_criteria: The system provides APIs for integrating with external version control systems (e.g., Git).
The system provides APIs for integrating with communication platforms (e.g., Slack, Microsoft Teams).
Integrated tools can automatically update ticket statuses or add comments based on external events (e.g., code commits).
Users can configure and manage third-party integrations from an admin panel.
The system ensures secure communication and data exchange with integrated platforms.

user_stories.title: Ensure System Scalability and Performance

user_story.i_want: to ensure the ticket management system is scalable and performs well under heavy load
user_story.so_that: I can confidently support a growing user base and increasing data volume without experiencing performance bottlenecks or downtime.

acceptance_criteria: The system maintains high performance and responsiveness even with a large number of users and tickets (e.g., 1000+ users, 100,000+ tickets).
The system architecture supports horizontal and vertical scaling to accommodate growth.
Database queries are optimized for fast retrieval and updates of ticket data.
The system can handle concurrent user requests without degradation in performance.
Load testing demonstrates the system's ability to meet performance benchmarks.

user_stories.title: Admin Panel for System Configuration and Management

user_story.i_want: to have a dedicated admin panel for managing users, roles, projects, and system configurations
user_story.so_that: I can efficiently maintain the system, onboard new teams, and ensure the platform operates according to organizational policies.

acceptance_criteria: Admin can access a dedicated panel for managing users, roles, and permissions.
Admin can configure system-wide settings, such as default ticket types, statuses, and priorities.
Admin can manage projects, including creating new projects and archiving old ones.
Admin can view system logs and audit trails for administrative actions.
The admin panel provides tools for data backup and restoration.

user_stories.title: System Monitoring and Analytics

user_story.i_want: to monitor system usage, errors, and performance metrics
user_story.so_that: I can proactively identify and resolve issues, ensure system stability, and provide data-driven insights for continuous improvement.

acceptance_criteria: The system logs all user actions, system events, and errors.
Monitoring tools provide real-time insights into system performance (e.g., CPU usage, memory, network traffic).
Alerts are triggered for critical system errors or performance degradation.
Analytics dashboards display key metrics such as ticket creation rates, resolution times, and team productivity.
The system generates reports on user activity and feature usage for auditing and improvement purposes.

user_stories.title: Technical Operations for Deployment and Maintenance

user_story.i_want: to have robust tools and processes for deployment, maintenance, and technical support
user_story.so_that: I can ensure the continuous availability, reliability, and smooth operation of the ticket management system.

acceptance_criteria: The system provides automated deployment scripts and procedures for new releases.
The system includes tools for managing and applying database migrations.
The system offers robust backup and recovery mechanisms for all data.
Technical support documentation is available for common issues and troubleshooting steps.
The system allows for easy rollback to previous versions in case of critical issues.

user_stories.title: Report and Track Bugs

user_story.i_want: to report new bugs with detailed information and track their resolution
user_story.so_that: I can ensure software quality, provide clear communication to developers, and verify fixes efficiently.

acceptance_criteria: User can create a new ticket specifically categorized as a 'Bug'.
User can include detailed steps to reproduce the bug, expected results, and actual results.
User can attach screenshots or video recordings to the bug ticket.
User can assign the bug to a developer or team.
The system automatically sets the priority or severity based on predefined rules or user input.

current_prd.tam_description: Total Addressable Market for the Global Application Development Software Market, encompassing all tools used in the software development lifecycle, including project management, collaboration, and issue tracking software.
current_prd.tam_estimation_basis: Based on the global application development software market size in 2022.
current_prd.tam_source: Statista Application Development Software Market Report 2022
current_prd.sam_description: Serviceable Available Market for Agile Project Management Software specifically targeting Small to Medium-sized Businesses (SMBs) and Startups. This represents the segment of the broader application development software market focused on agile methodologies for smaller teams.
current_prd.sam_estimation_basis: Estimated 25% of TAM focused on agile project management, and 45% of that segment targeting SMBs and startups.
current_prd.sam_source: Industry reports on agile adoption rates, SMB software spending trends, and market segmentation analysis.
current_prd.som_description: Serviceable Obtainable Market, representing the realistic market share a new Agile Ticket Management System can capture within the SAM over a 5-year horizon, considering the competitive landscape and market entry challenges.
current_prd.som_estimation_basis: Conservative 2.5% market share estimate over 5 years, considering strong competition and the need for market penetration.
current_prd.som_source: Competitive analysis of existing agile project management tools, new market entrant success rates, and typical software adoption curves.
current_prd.pricing_model_basis: Subscription-based per user per month, with tiered plans for teams.
current_prd.advantage_summary: Tailored for agile methodologies, centralized dashboard for clear visibility, efficient collaboration, future AI-driven insights, enhanced collaboration tools, and seamless integration capabilities, specifically designed for SMBs and startups.

planned.model_content:
class Project < ApplicationRecord
  belongs_to :organization
  belongs_to :manager, class_name: 'User', optional: true

  has_many :tickets, dependent: :destroy

  rhino_owner :organization
  rhino_references [:organization, :manager]

  validates :name, presence: true, length: { maximum: 255 }
  validates :description, presence: true
  validates :start_date, presence: true
  validates :end_date, presence: true
  validates :end_date, comparison: { greater_than_or_equal_to: :start_date }
end
planned.migration_content:
class CreateProjects < ActiveRecord::Migration[7.2]
  def change
    create_table :projects do |t|
      t.string :name, null: false, limit: 255
      t.text :description, null: false
      t.datetime :start_date, null: false
      t.datetime :end_date, null: false
      t.references :organization, null: false, foreign_key: true
      t.references :manager, foreign_key: { to_table: :users }

      t.timestamps
    end
  end
end
planned.rails_model_generation_command_line: rails generate model Project name:string description:text start_date:datetime end_date:datetime organization:references manager:references

validations: validates :category, presence: true, inclusion: { in: %w[bug feature task], message: "%<value>s is not a valid category" }
validates :status, presence: true, inclusion: { in: %w[open in_progress resolved closed], message: "%<value>s is not a valid status" }
validates :priority, presence: true, inclusion: { in: %w[low medium high critical], message: "%<value>s is not a valid priority" }
planned.model_content:
class Ticket < ApplicationRecord
  belongs_to :project
  belongs_to :assignee, class_name: 'User', optional: true
  belongs_to :reporter, class_name: 'User'

  has_many :comments, dependent: :destroy
  has_many :attachments, dependent: :destroy

  rhino_owner :project
  rhino_references [:project, :assignee, :reporter]

  validates :title, presence: true, length: { maximum: 255 }
  validates :description, presence: true
  validates :category, presence: true, inclusion: { in: %w[bug feature task], message: "%<value>s is not a valid category" }
  validates :status, presence: true, inclusion: { in: %w[open in_progress resolved closed], message: "%<value>s is not a valid status" }
  validates :priority, presence: true, inclusion: { in: %w[low medium high critical], message: "%<value>s is not a valid priority" }
  validates :due_date, presence: true
end
planned.migration_content:
class CreateTickets < ActiveRecord::Migration[7.2]
  def change
    create_table :tickets do |t|
      t.string :title, null: false, limit: 255
      t.text :description, null: false
      t.string :category, null: false
      t.string :status, null: false
      t.string :priority, null: false
      t.datetime :due_date, null: false
      t.references :project, null: false, foreign_key: true
      t.references :assignee, foreign_key: { to_table: :users }
      t.references :reporter, null: false, foreign_key: { to_table: :users }

      t.timestamps
    end
  end
end
planned.rails_model_generation_command_line: rails generate model Ticket title:string description:text category:string status:string priority:string due_date:datetime project:references assignee:references reporter:references

planned.model_content:
class Comment < ApplicationRecord
  belongs_to :ticket
  belongs_to :commenter, class_name: 'User'

  rhino_owner :ticket
  rhino_references [:ticket, :commenter]

  validates :content, presence: true
end
planned.migration_content:
class CreateComments < ActiveRecord::Migration[7.2]
  def change
    create_table :comments do |t|
      t.text :content, null: false
      t.references :ticket, null: false, foreign_key: true
      t.references :commenter, null: false, foreign_key: { to_table: :users }

      t.timestamps
    end
  end
end
planned.rails_model_generation_command_line: rails generate model Comment content:text ticket:references commenter:references

planned.model_content:
class Attachment < ApplicationRecord
  belongs_to :ticket
  belongs_to :uploader, class_name: 'User'

  has_one_attached :file

  rhino_owner :ticket
  rhino_references [:ticket, :uploader]

  validates :file, presence: true
end
planned.migration_content:
class CreateAttachments < ActiveRecord::Migration[7.2]
  def change
    create_table :attachments do |t|
      t.references :ticket, null: false, foreign_key: true
      t.references :uploader, null: false, foreign_key: { to_table: :users }

      t.timestamps
    end
  end
end
planned.rails_model_generation_command_line: rails generate model Attachment ticket:references uploader:references
